subsection.title: Definition of Function
subsection.p: We often want to predict values of one variable from the values of a related variable. For example, when a physician prescribes a drug in a certain dosage, she needs to know how long the dose will remain in the bloodstream. A sales manager needs to know how the price of his product will affect its sales. A functionfunction is a special type of relationship between variables that allows us to make such predictions.
Suppose it costs $800 for flying lessons, plus $30 per hour to rent a plane. If we let C represent the total cost for t hours of flying lessons, then C=800+30t ~~~~ (t\ge 0) Thus, for example

The variable t is called the inputinput or independentindependent variable, and C is the outputoutput or dependentdependent variable, because its values are determined by the value of t. We can display the relationship between two variables by a table or by ordered pairs. The input variable is the first component of the ordered pair, and the output variable is the second component.

For this relationship, we can find the value of C for any given value of t. All we have to do is substitute the value of t into the equation and solve for C. Note that there can be only one value of C for each value of t.

assemblage.title: Definition of Function
assemblage.p: A functionfunction is a relationship between two variables for which a unique value of the outputoutput variable can be determined from a value of the inputinput variable.

note.p: What distinguishes functions from other variable relationships? The definition of a function calls for a unique value—that is, exactly one value of the output variable corresponding to each value of the input variable. This property makes functions useful in applications because they can often be used to make predictions.

li.p: The distance, d, traveled by a car in 2 hours is a function of its speed, r. If we know the speed of the car, we can determine the distance it travels by the formula d = r \cdot 2.

The cost of a fill-up with unleaded gasoline is a function of the number of gallons purchased. The gas pump represents the function by displaying the corresponding values of the input variable (number of gallons) and the output variable (cost).

Score on the Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) is not a function of score on an IQ test, because two people with the same score on an IQ test may score differently on the SAT; that is, a person’s score on the SAT is not uniquely determined by his or her score on an IQ test.

As part of a project to improve the success rate of freshmen, the counseling department studied the grades earned by a group of students in English and algebra. Do you think that a student's grade in algebra is a function of his or her grade in English?
Explain why or why not.
Phatburger features a soda bar, where you can serve your own soft drinks in any size. Do you think that the number of calories in a serving of Zap Kola is a function of the number of fluid ounces?
Explain why or why not.
No, students with the same grade in English can have different grades in algebra.
Yes, the number of calories is proportional to the number of fluid ounces.

As part of a project to improve the success rate of freshmen, the counseling department studied the grades earned by a group of students in English and algebra. Do you think that a student's grade in algebra is a function of his or her grade in English? Explain why or why not.

Phatburger features a soda bar, where you can serve your own soft drinks in any size. Do you think that the number of calories in a serving of Zap Kola is a function of the number of fluid ounces? Explain why or why not.
No, students with the same grade in English can have different grades in algebra.
Yes, the number of calories is proportional to the number of fluid ounces.

webwork.pg-code: $twoout = RadioButtons( ["A) The variables are related by a formula.", "B) The values of the input and output variables must be different.", "C) There cannot be two output values for a single input value.", "D) There cannot be two input values for a single output value."], 2, );

statement.p: What distinguishes a function from other variable relationships?

solution.p: There cannot be two output values for a single input value.

statement.p: What distinguishes a function from other variable relationships?

li.p: The variables are related by a formula.
The values of the input and output variables must be different.
There cannot be two output values for a single input value.
There cannot be two input values for a single output value.

subsection.p: A function can be described in several different ways. In the following examples, we consider functions defined by tables, by graphs, and by equations.

subsection.title: Functions Defined by Tables
subsection.p: When we use a table to describe a function, the first variable in the table (the left column of a vertical table or the top row of a horizontal table) is the input variable, and the second variable is the output. We say that the output variable is a function of the input.

li.p: The table below shows data on sales compiled over several years by the accounting office for Eau Claire Auto Parts, a division of Major Motors. In this example, the year is the input variable, and total sales is the output. We say that total sales, S, is a function of t.
The table below gives the cost of sending printed material by first-class mail starting July 10, 2022.

If we know the weight of the article being shipped, we can find the postage from the table. For instance, a catalog weighing 4.5 ounces would require $1.56 in postage. In this example, w is the input variable and p is the output variable. We say that p is a function of w.
The table below records the age and cholesterol count for 20 patients tested in a hospital survey.

According to these data, cholesterol count is not a function of age, because several patients who are the same age have different cholesterol levels. For example, three different patients are 51 years old but have cholesterol counts of 227, 209, and 216, respectively. Thus, we cannot determine a unique value of the output variable (cholesterol count) from the value of the input variable (age). Other factors besides age must influence a person’s cholesterol count.

note.p: Note that several different inputs for a function can have the same output. For example, the inputs 4.5 and 4.25 in part (b) of the Example above have output $1.56. However, a single input cannot have more than one output, as illustrated in part (c) of the Example.

introduction.p: Decide whether each table describes y as a function of x. Explain your choice.

li.p: Is y a function of x?
Is y a function of x?
No, for example, x=3.5 corresponds both to y=2.5 and also to y=4.
Yes, each value of x has exactly one value of y associated with it.

statement.p: Decide whether each table describes y as a function of x. Explain your choice.

li.p: No, for example, x=3.5 corresponds both to y=2.5 and also to y=4.
Yes, each value of x has exactly one value of y associated with it.

webwork.pg-code: $table = RadioButtons( ["A) The output values are all the same.", "B) The input values are not evely spaced.", "C) Two different input values have the same output value.", "D) Two different output values have the same input value."], 3, );

statement.p: How would you know if a table of values does not come from a function?

solution.p: Two different output values have the same input value.

statement.p: How would you know if a table of values does not come from a function?

li.p: The output values are all the same.
The input values are not evely spaced.
Two different input values have the same output value.
Two different output values have the same input value.

subsection.title: Functions Defined by Graphs
subsection.p: We can also use a graph to define a function. The input variable is displayed on the horizontal axis, and the output variable on the vertical axis.

statement.p: The graph shows the number of hours, H, that the sun is above the horizon in Peoria, Illinois, on day t, where t = 0 on January 1.

li.p: Which variable is the input, and which is the output?
How many hours of sunlight are there in Peoria on day 150?
On which days are there 12 hours of sunlight?
What are the maximum and minimum values of H, and when do these values occur?
The input variable, t, appears on the horizontal axis. The number of daylight hours, H, is a function of the date. The output variable appears on the vertical axis.
The point on the curve where t = 150 has H \approx 14.1, so Peoria gets about 14.1 hours of daylight when t = 150, which is at the end of May.
H = 12 at the two points where t \approx 85 (in late March) and t \approx 270 (late September).

The maximum value of 14.4 hours occurs on the longest day of the year, when t \approx 170, about three weeks into June. The minimum of 9.6 hours occurs on the shortest day, when t \approx 355, about three weeks into December.

introduction.p: The graph shows the elevation in feet, a, of the Los Angeles Marathon course at a distance d miles into the race. (Source: Los Angeles Times, March 3, 2005)

li.p: Which variable is the input, and which is the output?
What is the elevation at mile 20?
Answer: feet
At what distances is the elevation 150 feet?
The relevant distances (to the nearest half-mile) separated by commas: miles
What are the maximum and minimum values of a , and when do these values occur?
The maximum elevation is a= feet which occurs at d= .
The runners pass by the Los Angeles Coliseum at about 4.2 miles into the race. What is the elevation there?
Approximately (within 5) feet
The input variable is d , and the output variable is a .
Approximately 210 feet
Approximately where d\approx 5 , d\approx 11 , d\approx 12 , d\approx 16 , d\approx 17.5 , and d\approx 18
The maximum value of 300 feet occurs at the start, when d = 0 . The minimum of 85 feet occurs when d\approx 15 .
Approximately 165 feet

subsection.title: Functions Defined by Equations
subsection.p: illustrates a function defined by an equation.

example.p: As of 2020, One World Trade Center in New York City is the nation’s tallest building, at 1776 feet. If an algebra book is dropped from the top of One World Trade Center, its height above the ground after t seconds is given by the equation h = 1776 - 16t^2 Thus, after \alert{1} second the book’s height is h = 1776 - 16(\alert{1})^2 = 1760 \text{ feet} After \alert{2} seconds its height is h = 1776 - 16(\alert{2})^2 = 1712 \text{ feet} For this function, t is the input variable and h is the output variable. For any value of t, a unique value of h can be determined from the equation for h. We say that h is a function of t.

statement.p: Write an equation that gives the volume, V, of a sphere as a function of its radius, r.
statement.instruction: Note: Use "pi" to enter the number \pi.

statement.p: Write an equation that gives the volume, V, of a sphere as a function of its radius, r.

statement.p: Name three ways to describe a function.
Name three ways to describe a function.

By tables, equations, or graphs
By the intercepts, the slope, or the vertex
By numbers, letters, or diagrams

technology.title: Making a Table of Values with a Calculator
technology.p:
We can use a graphing calculator to make a table of values for a function defined by an equation. For the function in , h = 1776 - 16t^2 we follow the steps:
Enter the equation: Press the Y= key, clear out any other equations, and define Y_1 = 1776 - 16X^2.
Choose the x-values for the table. Press 2ndWINDOW to access the TblSet (Table Setup) menu and set it to look like the figure at left below.
This setting will give us an initial x-value of 0 (TblStart = 0) and an increment of one unit in the x-values, (\Delta Tbl = 1). It also fills in values of both variables automatically.

ul.li: Press 2nd GRAPH to see the table of values, as shown in the figure at right below. From this table, we can check the heights we found in .

technology.p: Now try making a table of values with TblStart = 0 and \Delta Tbl = 0.5. Use the and arrow keys to scroll up and down the table.

statement.p: Write one question you still have about functions.
Write one question you still have about functions.

subsection.title: Function Notation
subsection.p: There is a convenient notation for discussing functions. First, we choose a letter, such as f, g, or h (or F, G, or H), to name a particular function. (We can use any letter, but these are the most common choices.)

For instance, in , the height, h, of a falling algebra book is a function of the elapsed time, t. We might call this function f. In other words, f is the name of the relationship between the variables h and t. We write h = f (t) which means "h is a function of t, and f is the name of the function."

warning.p: The new symbol f(t), read "f of t," is another name for the height, h. The parentheses in the symbol f(t) do not indicate multiplication. (It would not make sense to multiply the name of a function by a variable.) Think of the symbol f(t) as a single variable that represents the output value of the function.

subsection.p: With this new notation we may write h = f (t) = 1776 - 16t^2 or just f (t) = 1776 - 16t^2 instead of h = 1776 - 16t^2 to describe the function.

note.p: Perhaps it seems complicated to introduce a new symbol for h, but the notation f(t) is very useful for showing the correspondence between specific values of the variables h and t.

example.p: In , the height of an algebra book dropped from the top of One World Trade Center is given by the equation h = 1776 - 16t^2 We see that
Using function notation, these relationships can be expressed more concisely as

which we read as "f of 1 equals 1760" and "f of 2 equals 1712." The values for the input variable, t, appear inside the parentheses, and the values for the output variable, h, appear on the other side of the equation.

subsection.p: Remember that when we write y = f(x), the symbol f(x) is just another name for the output variable.

statement.p:
True or False.
The notation f(t) indicates the product of f and t.
If y=f(x), then f(x) gives the value of the input variable.
If Q is a function of M, we may write M=f(Q).
In the equation d=g(n) the letters d,~g, and n are variables.

Decide whether each statement is true or false.
The notation f(t) indicates the product of f and t.
If y=f(x), then f(x) gives the value of the input variable.
If Q is a function of M, we may write M=f(Q).
In the equation d=g(n) the letters d,~g, and n are variables.

li.p: Use function notation to state that H is a function of t.
What does the statement F(15) = 9.7 mean in the context of the problem?
The sun is above the horizon in Peoria for 9.7 hours on January 16.

subsection.title: Using Function Notation
subsection.p: Finding the value of the output variable that corresponds to a particular value of the input variable is called evaluating the functionevaluating the function.

statement.p: Let g be the name of the postage function defined by the table in b. Find g(1), g(3), and g(6.75).

solution.p: Thus, a letter weighing 1 ounce costs $0.60 to mail, a letter weighing 3 ounces costs $1.08, and a letter weighing 6.75 ounces costs $2.04.

statement.p: When you exercise, your heart rate should increase until it reaches your target heart rate. The table shows target heart rate, r = f(a) , as a function of age.

li.p: Find f(25) and f(50) .
Find a value of a for which f(a) = 135 .

webwork.pg-code: $inout = RadioButtons( ["\(f\) is the output and \(n\) is the input", "\(a\) is the input and \(f\) is the output", "\(a\) is the input and \(n\) is the output", "\(f(a)\) is the input and \(n\) is the output"], 2, );

statement.p: If n=f(a), what are the input and output variables?

solution.p: a is the input and n is the output

statement.p: If n=f(a), what are the input and output variables?

li.p: f is the output and n is the input.
a is the output and f is the input.
a is the output and n is the input.
f(a) is the output and n is the input.

subsection.p: If a function is described by an equation, we simply substitute the given input value into the equation to find the corresponding output, or function value.

statement.p:
The function H is defined by H=f(s) = \dfrac{\sqrt{s+3}}{s}. Evaluate the function at the following values.
s=6
s=-1

li.p: f(\alert{6})=\dfrac{\sqrt{\alert{6}+3}}{\alert{6}}= \dfrac{\sqrt{9}}{6}=\dfrac{3}{6}=\dfrac{1}{2}~. Thus, ~f(6)=\dfrac{1}{2}.
f(\alert{-1})=\dfrac{\sqrt{\alert{-1}+3}}{\alert{-1}}= \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{-1}=-\sqrt{2}~. Thus, ~f(-1)=-\sqrt{2}.

statement.p: Complete the table displaying ordered pairs for the function f(x) = 5 - x^3. Evaluate the function to find the corresponding f(x)-value for each value of x.
Complete the table displaying ordered pairs for the function f(x) = 5 - x^3. Evaluate the function to find the corresponding f(x)-value for each value of x.

technology.title: Evaluating a Function
technology.p: We can use the table feature on a graphing calculator to evaluate functions. Consider the function of , f(x) = 5 - x^3.
We can use the table feature on a graphing calculator to evaluate functions. Consider the function of , f(x) = 5 - x^3.

li.p: Press Y=, clear any old functions, and enter
\qquad Y_1=5-X ^ 3

ul.li: Press TblSet (2nd WINDOW) and choose Ask after Indpnt, as shown in the figure at left below, and press ENTER. This setting allows you to enter any x-values you like.
To follow , key in (-) 2 ENTER for the x-value, and the calculator will fill in the y-value. Continue by entering 0, 1, 3, or any other x-values you choose.
To follow , key in (-) 2 ENTER for the x-value, and the calculator will fill in the y-value. Continue by entering 0, 1, 3, or any other x-values you choose.

technology.p: One such table is shown in the figure at right below.

If you would like to evaluate a new function, you do not have to return to the Y= screen. Use the and arrow keys to highlight Y_1 at the top of the second column. The definition of Y_1 will appear at the bottom of the display, as shown above. You can key in a new definition here, and the second column will be updated automatically to show the y-values of the new function.

subsection.p: To simplify the notation, we sometimes use the same letter for the output variable and for the name of the function. In the next example, C is used in this way.

statement.p: TrailGear decides to market a line of backpacks. The cost, C, of manufacturing backpacks is a function of the number, x, of backpacks produced, given by the equation C(x) = 3000 + 20x where C(x) is measured in dollars. Find the cost of producing 500 backpacks.

solution.p: To find the value of C that corresponds to x = \alert{500}, evaluate C(500). C(\alert{500}) = 3000 + 20(\alert{500}) = 13,000 The cost of producing 500 backpacks is $13,000.

statement.p: The volume of a sphere of radius r centimeters is given by V = V(r) = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 Evaluate V(10) and explain what it means.
statement.instruction: Note: You may use "pi" to enter the number \pi.
statement.p: V(10)= , which represents

solution.p: V(10) = 4000\pi/3\approx 4188.79 \text{ cm}^3 is the volume of a sphere whose radius is 10 cm.

statement.p: The volume of a sphere of radius r centimeters is given by V = V(r) = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 Evaluate V(10) and explain what it means.

solution.p: V(10) = 4000\pi/3\approx 4188.79 \text{ cm}^3 is the volume of a sphere whose radius is 10 cm.

statement.p: Do linear equations y=mx+b and quadratic equations y=ax^2+bx+c define functions? Why or why not?
Do linear equations y=mx+b and quadratic equations y=ax^2+bx+c define functions? Why or why not?

subsection.title: Operations with Function Notation
subsection.p: Sometimes we need to evaluate a function at an algebraic expression rather than at a specific number.

statement.p: TrailGear manufactures backpacks at a cost of C(x) = 3000 + 20x for x backpacks. The company finds that the monthly demand for backpacks increases by 50% during the summer. The backpacks are produced at several small co-ops in different states.

ol.li: If each co-op usually produces b backpacks per month, how many should it produce during the summer months?
What costs for producing backpacks should the company expect during the summer?

An increase of 50% means an additional 50% of the current production level, b. Therefore, a co-op that produced b backpacks per month during the winter should increase production to b + 0.5b, or 1.5b backpacks per month in the summer.
The cost of producing 1.5b backpacks will be C(\alert{1.5b}) = 3000 + 20(\alert{1.5b}) = 3000 + 30b

statement.p:
A spherical balloon has a radius of 10 centimeters.
If we increase the radius by h centimeters, what will the new volume be?
If h = 2 , how much did the volume increase? Round your answer to hundredths.
It increased by \text{cm}^3 .
statement.instruction: Note: Use "pi" to enter the number \pi .

li.p: From V(10) to V(12) is an increase of about 3049.44 \text{ cm}^3

statement.p: A spherical balloon has a radius of 10 centimeters.

statement.p: Evaluate the function f(x)=4x^2 - x + 5 for the following expressions.

warning.p: In , notice that f(2h) \ne 2 f(h) and f(a + 3) \ne f(a) + f(3) To compute f(a) + f(3), we must first compute f(a) and f(3), then add them:

In general, it is not true that f(a + b) = f(a) + f(b). Remember that the parentheses in the expression f(x) do not indicate multiplication, so the distributive law does not apply to the expression f(a + b).

statement.p: Define the function f(x)=x^2. Which of these is equal to f(x+y)?
Define the function f(x)=x^2. Which of these is equal to f(x+y)?

Let f(x) = x^3 - 1 and evaluate each expression.
f(2) + f(3)=
f(2 + 3)=
2 f(x) + 3
Let f(x) = x^3 - 1 and evaluate each expression.
Explain why f(a+b) is not the same as f(a)+f(b) for most functions.
Explain why f(a+b) is not the same as f(a)+f(b) for most functions.
